overview_of_class: In this introductory music class, students will develop tools for describing, interpreting, and evaluating music as it relates to politics, race, class, gender, and other aspects of culture and identity, with a primary focus on the United States. Beginning with foundational knowledge gained through analysis of music as it relates to current events, the class will expand these dialogues to investigate other historical moments through music. Students will be evaluated through journals, attendance and participation, and a final project involving research into music chosen by the individual student.

overview_of_class: Music is all around us. Today, whether we are at a concert or in an elevator, music is an integral part of our experiences. Why do we like the music that we like? What about the music that we don't like? Primarily using examples from Western art (Classical) music, this class will consider both universal and culturally specific attributes of musical traditions. Class members will become engaged and critical listeners, consider the backgrounds of music, and develop the concepts necessary to discuss what they hear. This class requires no prior musical training; all students are welcome regardless of past musical experience. Students are expected to complete reading and listening assignments ahead of class meetings, engage with class lectures, participate in discussions, attend concerts (discounted and sometimes free admissions are available for Northwestern University students both on campus and around the Chicago area), submit written assignments, and prepare for quizzes or exams.
